introduction.p:
Earlier we derived Newton's second law for rotation of a rigid body about a fixed axis to be
\mathcal{T}_{\text{net,ext}} = I\,\alpha,
(Calculus step) Now, let us integrate both sides over an interval of time, say from t=t_i to t=t_f. We will get
\int_{t_i}^{t_f} \mathcal{T}_{\text{net,ext}}\, dt = \int_{t_i}^{t_f} I\,\alpha\, dt.
We recognize the left side as just the net rotational impulse. Now, on the right side, suppose we replace \alpha on the right side by d\omega/dt, cancel out dt, and then complete the integral. We get
J_{\text{rot,net}} = I \omega_f - I \omega_i,
where \omega_i and \omega_f are angular velocities at the initial and final instants. Since I\omega is angular momentum for rotation about a principal axis, find that net impulse equals change in angular momentum.
J_{\text{rot,net}} = \Delta L,
where
\Delta L = L_f - L_i = I \omega_f - I \omega_i.

Another way of arriving at result in Eq. is by looking at plots. If we plot both sides of Eq. versus time and compare the areas under the two curves, the left side gives the change in angular momentum and the right side gives the net rotational impulse by external forces as shown in .

figure.caption: The area under I\alpha versus t during t_i to t_f gives the change in angular momentum, \Delta L = L_f - L_i and the equal area under torque \mathcal{T} versus t gives the rotational impulse.

remark.p: We have derived Eq. from Eq. , which is, strictly speaking, only correct if we assume I is constant in time. So, it would appear that we should not use Eq. if I is changing.

However, more general considerations in a different derivation shows that if moment of inertia varies during the time interval, say from being I_i at t_i to I_f at t_f, then, you can still use Eq. , but now, we will have to use a different formula for \Delta L.
\Delta L = I_f\omega_f - I_i\omega_i

example.title: Rotational Impulse Causing Change in Angular Momentum

statement.p: The plot in shows net torque (with countercloclwise positive) on a disk of moment of inertia 5.0\text{ kg.m}^2 as a function of time. At t=0, the disk is rotating at angular velocity 2.0\text{ rad/s} in the clockwise direction. What is the magnitude and sense of rotation of the angular velocity at t = 5.0\text{ sec}?

solution.p:
We will use J_\text{rot}^\text{net} = \Delta L with J_\text{rot}^\text{net} = area under the curve, \Delta = (I\omega)_f - (I\omega)_i to find \omega_f. The area above zero torque give positive impulse and that below give negative impulse.
J_\text{rot}^\text{net} = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 10 \times 3 + (-5\times 2) = 15-10 = 5\text{ N.m.s}.
Now, note that \omega_i = -2\text{ rad/s} since it is clockwise and we are using counterclockwise sense as positive. Therefore, rotational impulse/change in angular momentum gives
5\,\omega_f - 5 \times (-2) - 5.
Therefore,
\omega_f = -1.0\text{ rad/s}.
Therefore, the final angular velocity is 1.0\text{ rad/s} in the clockwise direction.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Change in Angular Momentum by a Rotational Impulse
subsection.p:
From the general second law of motion,
\vec F =\dfrac{d\vec p}{dt},
we derived before that
\dfrac{ d\vec L }{dt} = \vec{\mathcal{T}}.
Multiply both sides by dt , we can integrate this from t= t_i to t= t_f .
\int_{t_i}^{t_f}\vec{\mathcal{T}}\,dt = \vec L_f - \vec L_i,
which is the statment that net external rotational impulse equals the change in angular momentum.
\vec{J}_\text{rot} = \vec L_f - \vec L_i.
